nodes.name: Mass economic suffering in vulnerable populations during transformative AI deployment
aliases: mass suffering from AI economic disruption
global hardship during AI uncanny valley
nodes.description: Risk that rapid, AI-induced economic changes harm hundreds of millions of people, particularly outside the US and Western Europe, before AI dividends are shared.
nodes.node_rationale: Central risk articulated throughout the post; see 'An Illustration' section.

nodes.name: Delay in equitable distribution of AI-generated economic value
nodes.description: A period between creation of TAI and the point when its economic benefits reach the global poor, due to political, logistical and coordination hurdles.
nodes.node_rationale: Key mechanism producing harm; highlighted in 'Alignment, Deployment, Adaptation' and 'Illustration'.

nodes.name: Rapid economic disruption from transformative AI market dominance
nodes.description: TAI may quickly concentrate wealth and restructure labor markets, outpacing governments' ability to respond.
nodes.node_rationale: Identified under 'Some Other Relevant Factors' (hard takeoff, early transform).

nodes.name: Inevitability of adaptation gap even with aligned AI
aliases: uncanny valley between AI creation and benefit sharing
nodes.description: Author assumes that, despite alignment and good intentions, structural delays will create a harmful gap requiring proactive planning.
nodes.node_rationale: Core theoretical claim stated in 'Relevant Assumptions'.

nodes.name: Historical pattern of technological cataclysms disproportionately harming vulnerable groups
aliases: past economic shocks effect on poor
nodes.description: Evidence from previous technological and global catastrophes shows marginalized communities bear the brunt of disruption.
nodes.node_rationale: Cited in 'Some Other Relevant Factors' and used as supporting evidence.

nodes.name: Climate adaptation literature analogy to adaptation necessity
nodes.description: The post analogizes AI adaptation to widely-accepted need for climate adaptation, offering conceptual validation.
nodes.node_rationale: Referenced in 'Alignment, Deployment, Adaptation' and throughout as supporting analogy.

nodes.name: Develop AI adaptation strategies to protect vulnerable populations
nodes.description: Proposed body of work to design policies and structures that moderate harm during the adaptation gap.
nodes.node_rationale: 'AI Adaptation' is framed as a new focus area; see 'Alignment, Deployment, Adaptation' section.

nodes.name: Global policy mechanisms to redistribute AI dividends quickly
nodes.description: Design emphasis on creating instruments that channel AI-generated wealth to the global population without long delays.
nodes.node_rationale: Implicit insight motivating proposed policy mechanisms; drawn from 'Illustration'.

nodes.name: Universal basic income funded by AI-driven revenues
aliases: worldwide basic stipend from AI dividends
nodes.description: Mechanism: provide every human a purchasing-power-adjusted stipend financed by dues from affluent governments and leading AI companies.
nodes.node_rationale: One of three concrete mechanisms in 'Some Tentative Policy Suggestions'.

nodes.name: Expansion of national and global social safety nets
aliases: enhanced welfare structures for AI disruption
nodes.description: Mechanism: redirect national budgets and multinational support to build larger, more adaptable welfare systems.
nodes.node_rationale: Second mechanism in 'Some Tentative Policy Suggestions'.

nodes.name: Global fund for economic disruption assistance
aliases: World Bank-style intermediary fund for AI impacts
nodes.description: Mechanism: create an expanded, well-resourced international fund to support poor communities facing AI-driven disruption.
nodes.node_rationale: Third mechanism in 'Some Tentative Policy Suggestions'.

nodes.name: Implement global universal basic income prior to transformative AI
aliases: roll out worldwide basic income ahead of TAI
nodes.description: Action: legislate and operationalize a universally distributed, purchasing-power-adjusted stipend funded by AI dividend taxes or dues, before large-scale TAI deployment begins.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Policy roll-out happens during Deployment phase; referenced in 'Some Tentative Policy Suggestions'.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Only limited pilot studies (e.g., national UBI trials); no large-scale global implementation—classified as Experimental/Proof-of-Concept.
nodes.node_rationale: Specific actionable step derived from implementation mechanism.

nodes.name: Establish AI-triggered social safety nets within national budgets
aliases: scale national welfare for AI shocks
integrate AI contingency into social protection
nodes.description: Action: rebuild or enlarge domestic welfare programs with explicit triggers and funding lines linked to AI-related labor market shocks.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Requires government deployment before and during TAI roll-out.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Some precedents for conditional cash transfers and automatic stabilizers exist, but no AI-specific implementations.
nodes.node_rationale: Operationalizes the safety-net mechanism for direct government action.

nodes.name: Create international AI economic disruption fund via World Bank model
aliases: set up Financial Intermediary Fund for AI
nodes.description: Action: establish a multilateral fund, similar to the World Bank’s Financial Intermediary Fund, to channel resources quickly to low-income countries harmed by AI disruption.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Institutional creation and deployment of a global fund occur in the Deployment phase.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Conceptual precedents exist, but no dedicated AI fund—thus Experimental/Proof-of-Concept.
nodes.node_rationale: Implements the global fund mechanism with concrete institutional framing.
